title: Hispanic Florida police aide under investigation after saying black sergeant 'looked like a monkey'
text:
A Florida police aide is under investigation after he allegedly said a black sergeant looked ‘like a monkey’ before he was due to testify in a legal hearing involving the officer.

Pablo Espinoza, a public service aide for the Miami-Dade Police Department, has been reassigned to ‘administrative duties’ pending the outcome of the investigation into the alleged conduct, the Miami Herald reported.

Espinoza, who is Hispanic, is in charge of maintaining breath-test machines and frequently acts as an expert witness at administrative and criminal hearings.

It’s before one such hearing in September that defense attorney Michael Catalano accuses Espinoza of making a slur against one of his clients, Miami-Dade Schools Police Sgt. Tracy Moore, who had been arrested on a charge of drunk driving.

‘Your client looks like a monkey sitting there,’ Espinoza purportedly told Catalano, who said he was stunned by the unprovoked remark.

It’s before one such hearing in September that defense attorney Michael Catalano (above) accuses Espinoza of making a slur against one of his clients, Miami-Dade Schools Police Sgt. Tracy Moore, who had been arrested on a charge of drunk driving

‘I was shocked,’ Catalano told the Herald. ‘Nobody talks like that in 2019.’

Catalano informed Moore, who is African American, about the Slur but the lawyer did not confront Espinoza during the administrative hearing on September 4.

Instead, he ordered Espinoza to apologize within two hours, saying he would forget about the comment if he admitted to saying it.

The hearing, at a Florida Department of Motor Vehicles office in West Miami-Dade, was being held to determine whether Moore could keep her driver’s license.

‘I was disgusted by that and they have video in the hallway,’ Catalano wrote in a text. ‘Apologize and we drop it.’

The aide reportedly replied with a brief apology, indicating that he now considered the matter ‘done’. However, Catalano later resurfaced the incident during an October 7 deposition in the criminal case against Moore.

‘My client and I are very upset about this,’ Catalano wrote in a complaint the following day to Miami-Dade Police Director Juan Perez. ‘My client wants PSA Espinoza fired immediately.’

Public service aides are not sworn officers. Their duties generally include writing traffic-accident reports, directing traffic and answering questions from the public.

‘I can’t talk to you, bro,’ Espinoza told the newspaper in a phone call. ‘You know that.’

In a statement to DailyMail.com, department officials confirmed in a statement Tuesday that Espinoza had been reassigned pending an internal investigation.

‘The Miami-Dade Police Department takes all complaints seriously and are committed to the highest performance standards and ethical conduct,’ the statement said. ‘We hold ourselves accountable for our actions and take pride in a professional level of service and fairness to all.’
description: Pablo Espinoza, a public service aide for the Miami-Dade Police Department, has been reassigned to 'administrative duties' pending the outcome of the investigation into the alleged conduct.
